p: Allium cepa L. (onion) belongs to the family Liliaceae. It is distributed in Pakistan, Russia, America, India, Europe, and China. In medicines, its seeds, leaves and rhizome are used. For more than 6000Â years, Allium cepa has been cultivated and is used as a nutrient. The bulb is commonly utilized as a food component to give flavour and aroma to a number of dishes. Ethnobotanically its fresh juice is used for pain and swelling, as a treatment for bee or wasp stings. It also acts as anti-inflammatory and anti-asthmatic agents. Its extract or oil is effective against different microbes, intestinal worms, fungi and bacteria ( Wetli, 2004). It is also used for treating neurological and cardiovascular diseases. Onion is ethnobotanically used as: throat infection, stomach diseases, antidote, baldness, ear pain, common cold, diarrhea, cholera, cough, menstruation, clear face, fever, eye diseases, hepatitis, intestinal diseases, piles, constipation, influenza, and skin spots, appetizer, headache, and improve sperm production ( Khan et al., 2009).
